Company: Shell Chemical L.P. and Shell Chemical Yabucoa
Description: Shell Chemical L.P. and Shell Chemical Yabucoa agreed to install pollution reduction equipment on two petroleum refining facilities at an estimated cost of $6 million as part of two comprehensive Clean Air Act settlements. The two companies agreed to pay a combined $3.3 million civil penalty to the United States as well as Alabama and Louisiana and $200,000 to Louisiana organizations for environmental education and emergency operations.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced that Shell Oil and affiliated partnerships agreed to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act at a large refinery and chemical plant in Deer Park, Texas, by spending at least $115 million to control harmful air pollution from industrial flares and other processes, and by paying a $2.6 million civil penalty. Shell agreed to spend $1 million on a state-of-the-art system to monitor benzene levels at the fenceline of the refinery and chemical plant near a residential neighborhood and school and to make the data available to the public through a website.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Shell Oil Company agreed to pay $110 million to resolve claims under the False Claims Act and administrative claims that Shell underpaid royalties due for oil produced on federal leases from 1980 to December 31, 1998.

Shell Oil Company agreed to pay $49 million to settle claims under the False Claims Act and various administrative provisions relating to its unauthorized venting and flaring of gas in the Gulf of Mexico.

Shell Oil Company and other Shell affiliates agreed to pay the United States $2.2 million to resolve claims that the companies violated the False Claims Act by knowingly underpaying royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal leases.

Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case, Motiva Enterprises LLC, Equilon Enterprises LLC, and Deer Park Refining Limited Partnership, which jointly operated nine oil refineries, agreed to spend $400 million to reduce emissions, pay a $9.5 million civil penalty and spend $5.5 million on supplementary environmental projects. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally between the three.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Equilon Enterprises LLC, and Deer Park Refining Limited Partnership
Description: Motiva Enterprises LLC, Equilon Enterprises LLC, and Deer Park Refining Limited Partnership -- participants in an alliance that operated nine petroleum refineries, agreed to pay $15 million -- consisting of a $9.5 million civil penalty and $5.5 million in spending on environmental projects -- to Delaware, Louisiana, the Northwest Air Pollution Authority and the federal government to resolve Clean Air Act violations. The announcement did not indicate how the total was to be divided among the companies. Here we assume it was divided evenly between Royal Dutch Shell (owner of Equilon and Deer Park) and Motiva (now owned by Saudi Aramco). This was part of a larger $415 million settlement announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-motiva-enterprises-llc-equilon-enterpris
Jiffy Lube agreed to pay $500,000 to the state as part of a settlement in which it agreed to improve its operations to prevent leaks of and oil and antifreeze into the ground.

Five oil producers -- Conoco, Unocal, Amerada Hess, Energen and Shell  -- agreed to pay a total of $21.8 million in settlement of claims they had underpaid severance taxes owed to the state for oil production. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided evenly among them.

Shell Chemical agreed to pay $622,000 to Alabama and $184,630 to Louisiana to resolve Clean Air Act violations (these amounts come from the consent decree linked below). This was part of a larger $9.5 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-shell-chemical-lp-and-shell-chemical-yab

Shell Oil agreed to pay $10 million in damages, make $10 million in donations to environmental projects, and donate 100 acres of land, in settlement of allegations its pesticide manufacture caused environmental contamination at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal. The U.S. Army paid also settled for contamination caused by chemical weapons production at the same location.
Shell Oil Co. agreed to pay $275,000 in settlement of alleged violations when a pipeline spill contaminated soil and groundwater west of Kankakee
Shell Oil Co. agreed to pay $200,000 in settlement of alleged environmental violations caused by underground storage tanks at 18 filling stations.

Shell Oil agreed to pay $4 million in settlement of allegations it and its joint venture Motive Enterprises received reimbursement payments from a state fund for cleanup of gasoline station storage tanks, while also seeking and receiving payments from their insursers, when such recoveries require paying back the state fund.

Shell Oil Company and Sunoco, Inc. agreed to pay a total of $35 million to settle their role in a lawsuit initiated in 2003 concerning groundwater contamination by the gasoline additive MTBE. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided evenly between them.

After finding hundreds of environmental violations at Shell gasoline stations statewide, the California Attorney General secured a $19.5 million judgment against Shell Oil Company and its affiliates designed to ensure compliance with the state's hazardous waste and underground fuel storage laws.
Shell agreed to pay $100,000 as part of the settlement of multistate litigation aimed at reducing the sale of tobacco products to minors.

Shell Pipeline Company LP agreed to pay $105,000 to the Illinois Environmental Protection Trust Fund and $50,000 to the Kane County Electronics Recycling Program in settlement of allegations of dumping contaminated soil at a Kane County landfill.

Company: Equilon Enterprises, LLC dba Shell Oil
Description: Equilon Enterprises agreed to pay $762,500 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Santa Clara, Alameda, Monterey, Napa, Santa Cruz, Solano and Sonoma counties that it failed to adequately inform customers about limitations applying to its gift and reward cards and did not provide some customers with advertised discounts.

Company: Equilon Enterprises, LLC dba Shell Oil
Description: Equilon agreed to pay $10.75 million to the San Diego County District Attorney and the San Diego City Attorney to resolve allegations of environmental violations at gas stations dating back to 1999.
Info Source: Gas station suit to cost Shell dearly; $10.75 million deal made with S.D. county, city, San Diego Union-Tirbune, October 13, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Jiffy Lube agreed to pay a total of $209,000 to Santa Clara County, the State of California, and the City of Santa Clara, in settlement of allegations  that it failed to follow state regulations that protect against discharge of hazardous waste and ensure fire safety.

Info Source: Shell to pay $675,000 in penalties Shell to pay $675,000 for refinery soot, Contra Costa Times, October 18, 2002 (via Nexis).

Description: Shell Oil agreed to pay Orange County $14.5 million to settle a lawsuit over groundwater contamination from the now-banned fuel additive MTBE at scores of gas stations. The total included $10.5 million for a study t determine the full extent of the contamination, which the company agreed to clean up.
Info Source: Shell Oil to shell out; Company will pay $14.5 million to settle O.C. groundwater contamination suit, Orange County Register, January 7, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Shell, Mobil, Texaco and Kinder Morgan agreed to pay a total of $700,000 in settlement of allegations that two sites the companies used in San Diego for fuel storage or pipelines had contaminated soil and groundwater. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here was assume the total was divided equally among them.

Agency: New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs
Info Source: Jiffy Lube to Pay $100,000 in Settlement with State, The Record (Bergen, NJ), August 9, 2001 (via Nexis).

Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue
Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Shell Oil Company and Motiva Enterprises
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Description: Shell Oil agreed to pay the United States $56 million to resolve claims that it underpaid royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal leases. The settlement resolved allegations that Shell systematically underreported the value of natural gas that it produced on federal leases in the Gulf of Mexico from August 1, 1986 to December 31, 1999 and, consequently, paid less royalties than it owed to the government.

Description: The Commission and Shell Energy North America (US), L.P. (SENA) reached a settlement to resolve an investigation into whether SENA engaged in a related-positions fraudulent scheme involving physical trading for the purpose of benefiting related financial positions during the May 2016 bidweek (April 25-29, 2016), in violation of section 4A of the Natural Gas Act (NGA) and the Commission's Anti-Manipulation Rule, SENA stipulated to the facts set forth in Section II of the Agreement, but neither admitted nor denied the alleged violations. SENA also agreed to annual compliance monitoring for two years.
A jury ordered Shell to pay $63 million for failing to adequately warn of the dangers of the chemical TCP contained in its farm fumigants.
A jury ordered Shell to pay $22 million for failing to adequately warn of the dangers of the chemical TCP contained in its farm fumigants.
Private Litigation Case Title: City of Clovis v. Shell Oil Company et al.

Description: Shell agreed to pay $5.8 million and change its practices to resolve a lawsuit relating to air pollution from its refinery and chemical plant in Deer Park, Texas.
Private Litigation Case Title: Environment Texas Citizen Lobby, Inc. et al v. Shell Oil Company et al

Description: Equilon Enterprises and Premcor agreed to pay $16 million for their part in a case in which residents of Hartford, Illinois sued oil and pipeline companies for creating an underground petroleum lake that released harmful vapors into the air. The court did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was split evenly between them.

Shell, Exxon Mobil and ChevronTexaco agreed to pay a total of $92.5 million to resolve a lawsuit brought by Santa Monica alleging that they contaminated the city's water supplies with the gasoline additive MTBE. It was not disclosed how much each company would pay; here we assume they each paid one-third of the total. The companies also agreed to pay for a water treatment plant expected to cost several hundred million dollars.
Shell Oil agreed to pay $28 million to settle litigation related to MTBE contamination of the water supply in South Lake Tahoe, California.
Private Litigation Case Title: SO. TAHOE PUBLIC VS. ATLANTIC RICHFIELD
